name: 陳岡伯
objective:
本課程以當代文學批評和文化理論為基礎，探討小說與戲劇改編成電影的過程中，文字轉化成視覺意象之間的差異，期能提升多元化的思辯及表達能力。
Drawing upon modern literary criticism and cultural theory, this course aims to examine the difference between works of literature and the distinctive medium of the cinema. Students will be offered a variety of discussion which stimulates the kinds of critical thinking that lead to a better understanding of the process of transposition from literature to film.

The course follows the history of Western literature, approaching representative literary works from Classical antiquity, the Middle Age, Renaissance, the Enlightenment, the Romantic Period and the nineteenth century, to the modern time. Students will watch films related to or adapted from the literary texts, after which the instructor will give a lecture and conduct in-class discussion. By the end of the semester, the students will be familiarized with the key ideas of each important literary era or movement and formulate their own critical interpretations of literature and its visualization.
schedule:
Week 1: Introduction to the course

Week 2-3: Classical Antiquity
Film viewing: Troy (2004)
Literary text: Homer's Iliad

Week 4-5: The Middle Age
Film viewing: Kingdom of Heaven (2005)
Literary text: The Song of Roland

Week 6-7: Renaissance
Film viewing: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
Literary text: William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet and sonnets

Week 8-9: the Enlightenment
Film viewing: The Devil's Advocate
Literary text: John Milton's Paradise Lost

Week 10-11: the Years of Revolution
FIlm viewing: Quills (2000)
Literary text: Marquis de Sade's Justine, or the Misfortunes of Virtue

Week 12-13: the Romantic Period
Film viewing: Red Dragon (2002)
Literary text: William Blake's poetry

Week 14-15: the Victorian Age
Film viewing: Interview with the Vampire (1994)
Literary text: Bram Stoker's Dracula

Week 16-17: the Twentieth Century
Film viewing: The Hours (2002)
Literary text: Virginia Woolf's A Room of One's Own and Mrs. Dalloway

Week 18: Group presentations
scorePolicy:

Group presentation: 30%
Final paper: 40%
materials: Reading materials will be distributed by the instructor.
